Relations.title: Relations and Functions
Relations.summary: This chapter introduces sets, Cartesian products, relations, types of functions (one-one, onto, bijective), composition of functions, invertible functions, and binary operations. It lays the foundation for algebraic structures.
formulas: Cartesian product: A × B = {(a, b) | a ∈ A, b ∈ B}
Number of relations from A to B: 2^(n(A) × n(B))
Inverse function: f⁻¹(y) = x ⇔ f(x) = y
Identity element for binary operation: a * e = e * a = a
Inverse element for binary operation: a * a⁻¹ = a⁻¹ * a = e
derivations: Proof of equivalence relations (reflexive, symmetric, transitive)
Conditions for invertibility of a function (bijectivity)
Proof of properties of composite functions (e.g., associativity)
Proof of properties of binary operations (commutativity, associativity, identity, inverse)

Inverse-Trigonometric-Functions.title: Inverse Trigonometric Functions
Inverse-Trigonometric-Functions.summary: This chapter introduces the concept of inverse trigonometric functions, their domains, ranges, and principal value branches. It covers their graphs and various properties used in solving trigonometric equations and simplifying expressions.
derivations: Principal value branch of inverse trigonometric functions (conceptual)
Derivation of fundamental identities involving inverse trigonometric functions (e.g., sin⁻¹(x) + cos⁻¹(x) = π/2)
Proof of addition/subtraction formulas for inverse trigonometric functions

Matrices.title: Matrices
Matrices.summary: This chapter covers the fundamental concepts of matrices, including their types, operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication), and properties of matrix algebra. It also discusses transpose, symmetric, skew-symmetric matrices, elementary row/column operations, and the inverse of a matrix.
formulas: Identity matrix (I): A I = I A = A
Inverse of a matrix: A A⁻¹ = A⁻¹ A = I
For 2x2 matrix A = [[a, b], [c, d]], A⁻¹ = (1/det(A)) [[d, -b], [-c, a]]
derivations: Properties of matrix addition and scalar multiplication
Properties of matrix multiplication (associativity, distributivity)
Conditions for existence of inverse of a matrix
Elementary row/column operations for finding inverse (conceptual)

Determinants.title: Determinants
Determinants.summary: This chapter focuses on determinants, which are scalar values associated with square matrices. It covers minors, cofactors, properties of determinants, and their applications in finding the area of a triangle, adjoint and inverse of a matrix, and solving systems of linear equations using Cramer's rule.
formulas: Determinant of a 2x2 matrix: det(A) = ad - bc
Area of a triangle with vertices (x₁,y₁), (x₂,y₂), (x₃,y₃): ½ |det([[x₁, y₁, 1], [x₂, y₂, 1], [x₃, y₃, 1]])|
Adjoint of a matrix: adj(A) = (Cofactor matrix)ᵀ
Inverse of a matrix: A⁻¹ = (1/det(A)) adj(A)
Cramer's Rule for system of linear equations: x = Δₓ/Δ, y = Δᵧ/Δ, z = Δ₂/Δ
derivations: Properties of determinants (row/column operations, common factor, zero row/column, identical rows/columns)
Relation between adjoint and inverse of a matrix (A adj(A) = adj(A) A = det(A) I)
Consistency of system of linear equations using determinants

Continuity-Differentiability.title: Continuity and Differentiability
Continuity-Differentiability.summary: This chapter explores the concepts of continuity of functions at a point and in an interval, and differentiability. It introduces various rules of differentiation, including the chain rule, implicit differentiation, and differentiation of inverse trigonometric and exponential/logarithmic functions, along with Rolle's Theorem and Mean Value Theorem.
formulas: Condition for continuity: limₓ→c⁻ f(x) = limₓ→c⁺ f(x) = f(c)
Derivative from first principle: f'(x) = limₕ→₀ (f(x+h) - f(x))/h
derivations: Derivative of standard functions from first principles (e.g., xⁿ, sinx, cosx, eˣ, logx)
Derivation of chain rule, product rule, quotient rule
Rolle's Theorem and Mean Value Theorem (conceptual understanding and geometric interpretation)

Applications-of-Derivatives.title: Applications of Derivatives
Applications-of-Derivatives.summary: This chapter applies derivatives to various real-world problems. Key topics include rate of change of quantities, finding equations of tangents and normals to curves, identifying increasing and decreasing functions, and determining local maxima and minima using first and second derivative tests.
formulas: Rate of change: dA/dt, dV/dt, etc.
Equation of tangent: y - y₀ = (dy/dx)ₓ₀,y₀ (x - x₀)
Equation of normal: y - y₀ = [-1 / (dy/dx)ₓ₀,y₀] (x - x₀)
derivations: Conditions for increasing and decreasing functions
First derivative test for local maxima/minima
Second derivative test for local maxima/minima (conceptual)

Integrals.title: Integrals
Integrals.summary: This chapter introduces the concept of integration as the inverse process of differentiation. It covers indefinite and definite integrals, various methods of integration (substitution, integration by parts, partial fractions), and properties of definite integrals.
formulas: Integration by Parts: ∫u dv = uv - ∫v du
Definite Integral as limit of sum: ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx = limₕ→₀ h[f(a) + f(a+h) + ... + f(a+(n-1)h)] where nh = b-a
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus: ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx = F(b) - F(a) (where F'(x) = f(x))
derivations: Integration by substitution method
Integration by parts method
Integration by partial fractions method
Properties of definite integrals (e.g., ∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx = ∫ₐᶜ f(x)dx + ∫ᶜᵇ f(x)dx)
Definite integral as a limit of a sum (conceptual)

Applications-of-Integrals.title: Applications of Integrals
Applications-of-Integrals.summary: This chapter focuses on applying definite integrals to calculate the area of regions bounded by curves, lines, and axes. It includes finding the area under simple curves, areas between two curves, and applications in real-world scenarios.
formulas: Area under a curve y = f(x) from x=a to x=b: A = ∫ₐᵇ y dx
Area under a curve x = g(y) from y=c to y=d: A = ∫_cᵈ x dy
Area between two curves y=f(x) and y=g(x) from x=a to x=b: A = ∫ₐᵇ |f(x) - g(x)| dx
derivations: Geometric interpretation of definite integral as area under the curve
Method for finding the area between two curves (conceptual)
